title: REMINDING YOU WHAT QUALITY OF LIFE CHANGES MEANS
body:
Before you make a post saying "making some QOL changes to X champion" find out what QOL means.

QOL = Quality of life. Essentially anything that adds or takes away numbers from a champions abilities(_and stats_) is **NOT **a Quality of life change.
A QOL buff focuses on making the champion experience better without tinkering with their core mechanics and damage (_and stats_).

Here is a Quiz to help.

**1. Akali re-enters stealth while in W quicker.** (QOL OR NON QOL)

**2. Maokai has increased cooldown on his Q. **(QOL or NON QOL)

**3. Shaco's cast time for Q is reduced.** (QOL or NON QOL)

**4. Xerath's range indicator is more accurate for his Q when fully charged.** (QOL or NON QOL)




ANSWERS: 
1. NON QOL
2. NON QOL
3. NON QOL
4. QOL

Did an Edit, changes are  _italicized_ and (parenthesized)

replies.body:
You're actually conflating the concept of a QoL *change* with a QoL *buff*

4 is the only example of a purely QoL *change* but 1 and 3 are both changes that directly affect the *feel* or *quality of life* of the champions in question, however, that change is also a notable *buff*

You should actually have 2 definitions up there:

* QoL **Change**: any change that does not affect the stats of a champion and solely improves the user experience.
* QoL **Buff**: any change that affects statistics with the sole intention of making a champion have a better user experience.

and for the hell of it, here's the third (although much, much rarer) version of a QoL change:

* QoL **Nerf**: any change that directly reduces the quality of the user experience (this is almost exclusively for things like increased cast times (see Veigar's E nerf) and is usually considered a QoL buff for the champion's opponent. They also seem to be a lot rarer, since in general having more in game fluidity and a better user experience is optimal, and a QoL nerf is often not the best way to handle the situation).

EDIT: For some examples, 

* Thresh's hook hitbox indicator being adjusted to match in game functionality would be a QoL change.
* Pantheon having his attack time increased without actually increasing his attack speed was a QoL buff.
* Veigar's E having the warning particle start during cast was a QoL nerf (although it was tied to an overall buff when sent out).

I think part of the issue is that some straight buffs act like great QoL changes. For example if they nerfed{{champion:90}} ult range slightly it would definitely be a straight up nerf, not a QoL thing, and yet if it matched up with the range for casting {{summoner:14}} then it would definitely help the Quality of play with him because then I wouldn't accidentally cancel my ult by trying to ignite someone I'm ulting.

Basically it's a somewhat misleading term because I feel like the intention of the term is to indicate that something was changed that should make the champion feel better to play but not necessarily be stronger (except for the increased ease of play). The issue is a lot of changes that straight up make the champion stronger also make them easier to play, which is kind of QoL but isn't really the situation the term was intended for.

I'd say overall the "purest" QoL changes are the ones that the player using the champions notices, but his opponent does not. Things like clearer tooltips, better casting indicators, and allowing {{champion:43}}  and {{champion:74}} to ult when stunned would fall under this. Frankly I think the safest way to define it would be this way, so "Quality of Life changes" has a very clear meaning. We would then call things like changing AA animations and cast times to be called "skill cap buffs", and call increased damage or scaling to be "stat buffs". This would create a very clear terminology for the kind of changes that are taking place.
For example, Viktor and Kha'Zix upgrading their abilities kinda needs a QOL change _wink wink nudge nudge._

I feel like straight buffs/nerfs are primarily mechanical changes. Example: changing numbers, making a hitbox a different size (changing particles to match the hitbox is QOL), changing cooldowns, etc. These changes are primarily meant to increase/decrease power through direct manipulation of mechanics on how they are played, or the numbers behind the damage.

While QOL changes are meant to:
1. Have champions feel smoother in animations and look. If an AA animation change looks and feels smoother, but the casting time remains the same, it is QOL. On the other hand, if the AA animation changes the numerical value of the cast time, then it is a buff/nerf. See the difference?
2. Bring more transparency to the champion and/or game, particles were altered to fit the hitbox for example, rather than contradicting visuals vs reality. This way enemies know where things are (in the animation hitbox) and players aren't stuck wondering, "Why the hell didn't I hit them with that? It went right through them."
3. Fixing bugs that do not deliver the intended effect (although this can also be a buff, I prefer QOL since it is not actually changing the mechanics of a champion, but bringing them in line of where they were always intended to be). Example: Fixing the hitbox on Cassiopeia's ult. Her ult's hitbox was always strange, and sometimes a champion standing just a tad bit in front of her would not get ulted. It was a buff, but wasn't meant to increase power as much as giving players reliability and optimization when ulting. They were _always_ meant to be in the ult in that position, but it wasn't coded right to ensure reliability. Therefore, I call it a QOL fix.
4. Fixing Tooltip and UI for transparency and ease of use. The latest changes made in the game client that moved teammate position to a different part of the screen, and a cleaner looking shop, are QOL changes for all players and not dependent on any champion. Making it visually appealing doesn't directly affect a players strength, in numerical values.

There are probably more, but that's all I got off the top of my head.

Really depends on your definition. QoL stands for Quality of Life. Shaco having a reduced cast time on his Q certainly improves his Quality of Life. Of course, it's also a buff to him as well.

The two are not mutually exclusive.

To be pedantic about it, one could argue that any buff increases the quality of a champion's life.  From this view, all buffs are QOL increases, but not all QOL increases are actually buffs.  Colloquially, QOL increases that are not buffs are sometimes called "QOL changes".  Confusingly, the colloquial term is not used consistently.

**In colloquial use:**
Shrinking particle/indicator to fit actual AoE/range --> QOL fix
Growing AoE/range to fit particle --> Buff
